title: Simplify
excerpt: Select only essential features and information, and keep elements to a minimum. A fundamental principle across all design disciplines.

title: Make It Easy
excerpt: Streamline how it is used, reducing steps and effort to reach the goal as much as possible.

title: Mental Models
excerpt: Match the structure and behavior to the user's imagined model. Provide learnable idioms (conventions) that give users a model. Use metaphors to convey concepts and functionality.

title: Signifiers
excerpt: Make actionable elements visible and their meaning immediately clear. Use familiar expressions and obvious shapes to suggest how to use them. For example, make things that can be pressed look pressable, and things that cannot be pressed look unpressable.

title: Mapping
excerpt: Make the relationship between the controls and their effects easy to understand. Use cues like spatial arrangement, shape, color, and symbols.

title: Consistency
excerpt: Apply consistent rules to color, shape, layout, behavior, and so on. Use the same expression for the same properties, and different expressions for different properties. Consistency embodies the design's logic and is a key cue for users to infer and learn how the system works.

title: User Control
excerpt: Let users control the system, not the other way around. Reduce actions forced by system constraints. Don't unilaterally restrict user behavior for the system's convenience. Ensure users can always choose and proceed based on their own intent.

title: Direct Manipulation
excerpt: Create the feeling of directly manipulating on-screen objects. Update the display in real time in response to physical actions (feedback). Make it possible to return to the previous state by performing the opposite action (reversibility).

title: Be Modeless
excerpt: Eliminate modes as much as possible. In UI, a mode is when the meaning of an action changes depending on context, limiting what users can do or forcing a fixed sequence. A modeless UI lets users work in any order.

title: Visual Gestalt
excerpt: Human perception is shaped by overall structure rather than recognizing elements independently (Gestalt psychology). Use patterns like proximity, similarity, and closure (the law of Pragnanz) to lay out elements and effectively show grouping relationships.

title: Use the User's Language
excerpt: Use words users normally use, not internal technical terms or industry jargon.

title: Don't Rely on Memory
excerpt: Don't assume users remember message contents or property values. Information that must be referenced should be available at the moment it's needed.

title: Constraints
excerpt: Intentionally constrain user actions to reduce mistakes and encourage effective use. For example, scissors constrain how you hold them via the handle shape so the blades are oriented correctly (easy to apply force and easy to see the cut).

title: Precomputation
excerpt: Preset optimal values discovered by predecessors and reuse them in design. Examples include rice cooker markings, microwave cooking timers, automatic transmission shift timing, the target position in a bidet, and various program algorithms.

title: Prevent Errors
excerpt: Make errors less likely. Clear error messages matter, but it's more important to design so errors don't happen. Clearly distinguish confusing options, and disable actions that are meaningless in the current context.

title: Fitts's Law
excerpt: Pointing at on-screen elements with a mouse is faster when the target is closer and larger, and slower when it is farther and smaller. In other words, bigger and closer targets are easier to hit; smaller and farther targets are harder.

title: Hick's Law
excerpt: Choosing one option takes time proportional to the number of options. Even if you know what you want, more options still take more time.

title: Conservation of Complexity
excerpt: There is a limit to how much you can simplify a process. You can't eliminate complexity; you can only move it. By moving complexity from the user to the system as much as possible, you can improve usability.

title: Task Coherence
excerpt: Users are likely to do today what they did yesterday. This is called task coherence. Remembering only what users last did can have the same effect as accurately predicting their behavior.

title: Optimize for Common Tasks
excerpt: Bring forward the information and features that match the tasks most users do. 80% of users use only 20% of features (the Pareto principle). Treating all demands equally makes the result hard to use for everyone, so prioritize major demands.

title: Persuasion
excerpt: Use persuasive mechanisms to encourage user behavior. Motivate and support decision-making through usage guidance, recommendations, psychological rewards, comparisons with others, simulated experiences via VR or simulation features, and so on.

title: Provide Shortcuts
excerpt: For frequent actions by experienced users, provide faster methods that reduce the usual step-by-step operation: keyboard shortcuts, bookmarks, gestures, history, etc.

title: Be Object-Based
excerpt: Extract objects from requirements and reflect them in the UI. If you only expose procedural steps as features, the system becomes inefficient and hard to understand. Identify the underlying objects so users can act on them directly to achieve goals.

title: Views Represent Objects
excerpt: An interface is composed of a collection of views that represent objects (conceptual entities that are the focus of user interest). A single object can have different representations across multiple views.

title: Objects Embody Their State
excerpt: In a GUI, every on-screen object—icons, selectable items, controls, panes, windows—must continuously and visually embody its state in real time. Users change that state through interaction, bringing their work closer to a desired state.

title: Noun Then Verb
excerpt: Let users select the target (noun) first, then choose the action (verb). This is the basic GUI interaction order. If you make users choose the action first, you create a waiting-for-target state and reduce freedom.

title: Consistent Graphic Tone
excerpt: Keep tone and manner consistent across graphic elements: hue/saturation/brightness, gradients, borders, shadows, corner radius, fills and strokes, line thickness, representational vs abstract, and so on.

title: Communicate Meaning, Not Data
excerpt: Users want meaning, not raw numbers. For example, they'd rather know what percentage of disk space remains than how many bytes are used. When buying a music player, they'd rather know how many songs it holds than the exact capacity.

title: Automate Single-Option Actions
excerpt: If there is only one permitted input action, making the user do it adds zero value. The system should do it automatically.

title: Keep Tools Near the Work
excerpt: Place tools near the thing being worked on. If you must open another window while the object is visible, it's like getting up to search for a pen down the hall. Enable modeless, in-context actions and let users see results as they work.

title: Show Visually, Explain with Text
excerpt: Make objects and their state understandable visually, and supplement with text. Use icons to convey the nature of items and labels to clarify. Use graphics to show information and numbers to provide detail.

title: Surface Prerequisites Early
excerpt: Ask for prerequisites early, not halfway through or at the end of a long procedure, or you may waste the user's effort. Examples include input information needed from outside the app and agreements users must accept.

title: Use Nouns in Navigation
excerpt: When navigation items are phrased as verbs (things to do), it's harder to understand what's there, and building screens by action leads to many similar list screens. Create screens by information type, and use nouns for navigation.

title: Icons Represent Nouns or Adjectives
excerpt: Base icons on the object they symbolize (a noun) or the resulting state (an adjective). Since processes (verbs) are hard to depict, avoid making them icons except for a few common ones.

title: Bind Data
excerpt: When the same object is visible in multiple views at once, keep those views in sync. Two-way real-time updates let users feel they are acting directly on the object without worrying about internal processing.

title: Zero, One, Infinity
excerpt: Don't set arbitrary limits on counts. The number of elements should be 0, 1, or infinity. Don't limit things users can add, and ensure the UI doesn't break no matter how many there are.

title: Every Actionable Element Matters
excerpt: Every currently actionable element or selectable item must have meaning for the user's task. Meaningless elements hinder tasks just by existing, so disable or hide them.

title: User Input Belongs to Users
excerpt: Values and settings users enter should be saved by default. Items users add must be deletable by the user. Content users enter must be editable by the user.

title: Don't Ask for Inconsistent Inputs
excerpt: Don't ask users to perform actions that could compromise data consistency. For example, don't make them enter both date of birth and age.

title: Give Forms a Narrative
excerpt: Group input items into meaningful chunks. Order fields from familiar and simple first to complex later.

title: Create an Interaction Flow
excerpt: Use grouping and narrative ordering to guide users' eyes and actions. Action buttons suggest the end of the flow, so make the path to them easy to find.

title: Good Defaults
excerpt: Good defaults reduce user effort. Good defaults are lower-risk, more common, more neutral, reflect the current state, or reflect the user's past actions.

title: Use Constrained Controls
excerpt: When inputs must be constrained, use appropriate controls like radio buttons, dropdowns, steppers, sliders, and pickers so only valid values can be entered.

title: Use Affirmative Wording
excerpt: Make option text affirmative as much as possible. With on/off controls like radios and checkboxes, a negative label makes the act of selecting mean affirming a negation and is hard to understand.

title: Let Users Choose Outcomes
excerpt: Users often prefer selecting from options rather than typing. Instead of making them set parameter values directly, show the outcomes they can get and let them choose.

title: Structure Input Fields
excerpt: Split or constrain input fields to match the required format. This hints what to enter, improves efficiency, and reduces errors. But it can be less efficient than a simple text box, so consider the nature of the information and usage context.

title: Use Specific Verbs on Default Buttons
excerpt: In modal dialogs and forms, label the default (primary) button with a concrete verb that describes the action (e.g., Save, Delete) rather than OK or Yes.

title: Radio vs Checkbox
excerpt: Use radio buttons for single selection from options (with a default). Checkboxes are independent on/off items and can be used for multi-select. Use radios for A-or-B; use checkboxes for true/false.

title: Avoid the Flip-Flop Problem
excerpt: When one button toggles on and off, it's unclear whether the label describes the current state or the state after pressing; this is the flip-flop problem. Avoid it by separating state display from the label.

title: Don't Demand Mechanical Precision
excerpt: Reduce input-format strictness imposed for system convenience. Absorb variations like case, punctuation, and separators, and normalize or autocomplete internally. Don't demand mechanical precision from users.

title: Provide Input Suggestions
excerpt: Typing is costly, and users often prefer choosing. As they type, suggest what they were trying to enter or valuable values, effectively supporting the action.

title: Make It Look Scrollable
excerpt: If you want users to scroll a long vertical screen, don't align the bottom edge exactly with a content boundary, which can make it look unscrollable. Adjust content so it looks like there's more.

title: Show Previews in Choices
excerpt: When changing an object's style or choosing a tool, show the resulting state as previews in the choices. Seeing results before applying properties makes trial-and-error more efficient.

title: Fail-Safe Over Fool-Proof
excerpt: It's more important to be fail-safe (okay even if users make mistakes) than fool-proof (impossible to make mistakes). If everything can be undone, mistakes effectively disappear and all actions become part of productive exploration.

title: Constructive Error Messages
excerpt: When errors occur, help users understand and act with clear messages. Tell them what happened and what to do next. Error codes are useless for most users. Avoid overblown wording.

title: Possibility vs Probability
excerpt: Don't make normal use cumbersome by over-considering rare events. Designers should emphasize the main case. Treating main-case and edge-case features side by side makes interfaces complex and harms normal use.

title: Execute Quietly
excerpt: Don't ask for confirmation for everything or report every successful completion. Provide modeless feedback via changes on the screen, not dialogs. Ask for confirmation only for irreversible actions or those that may cause data loss.

title: Have the Guts to Simplify
excerpt: If you try to satisfy every design requirement, you may never ship anything coherent. Design requires the guts to make trade-offs. Prioritizing completeness and strictness too much can add options and obscure the core intent.

title: Wayfinding
excerpt: Provide signposts so users don't get lost in an information space: where they are, where they can go, what's nearby, how to go back, etc. Use a consistent navigation scheme so users can grasp the overall structure.

title: Escape Hatch
excerpt: Provide an escape hatch so users can always return quickly to the starting place. In home-based navigation or when entering a specific mode, make it easy to get back to the base screen when users feel lost or want to stop.

title: Immediate Gratification
excerpt: Ensure users can experience success within a few seconds of starting to use the product. Show the most basic working screen or object list as early as possible so they can start immediately, and help them feel they are making legitimate progress.

title: Defer Decisions
excerpt: Don't demand every decision upfront. Allow users to defer non-essential answers: use some features without an account, create records without filling every attribute, etc. In forms, require only fields whose necessity is clear.

title: Animate State Changes
excerpt: When changing a large portion of the screen, add transition animation so users can understand continuity between states. Show intermediate steps over about 0.1-0.5 seconds.

title: Bidirectional Transitions
excerpt: When animating a transition from state A to B, also animate the reverse transition from B back to A. Corresponding direction helps users form a correct mental model of the information space.

title: Respond Within 0.1 Seconds
excerpt: Return feedback as quickly as possible. Around 0.1 seconds is the limit where users feel it is instantaneous. Up to 1 second is tolerable without breaking their train of thought. Beyond about 10 seconds, show progress and remaining time.

title: Feedback Near the Action
excerpt: When indicating system state changes in response to user actions, give feedback near where the user is looking. If it's an action on a selected object, change the object itself. If it's a single button, indicate it near that button.

title: Progressive Disclosure
excerpt: Hide advanced features at first so beginners can start easily, and reveal them when needed or when the user is ready. This enables staged learning.

title: Avoid Culture-Specific Icons
excerpt: Icons are often symbolic, but avoid symbols based on signs used only in specific cultures or language-dependent idioms in international services.

title: Account for Label Length in Localization
excerpt: Average word length differs by language. German is generally long (about 1.4x English on average) and is useful for quick layout stress tests. Conversely, CJK and Korean labels are shorter, so ensure buttons and such don't become too small to tap.

title: Avoid Ambiguous Symbols
excerpt: In Japan, ○ and × mean good and bad, but these nuances differ by culture, so such symbols may not communicate in international interfaces. For example, × can be used with a positive nuance meaning a checkmark.

title: Prefer Conventions
excerpt: UI is often said to be best when it's intuitive, but what people often mean is conventional. Double-clicking to open files and pinching to zoom must be learned at first. Use idioms people already know, and if proposing new interactions, make them naturally learnable and eventually conventional.

title: Follow Platform Button Order
excerpt: For confirm/cancel button order in dialogs, prioritize user habit and follow platform rules. If there is no clear rule, follow the common sense that left is back and right is forward, and put the confirm button on the right.

title: Keep Menu Items Stable
excerpt: In menus listing actions or navigation items, keep item positions stable across contexts. Users remember the location spatially; if positions change, they can't learn.

title: Minimal Highlight Changes
excerpt: To highlight one item among peers, change only one visual component (or add only one). If the change is too large, it stops reading as a highlight and looks like a different kind of element.

title: Consider Optical Illusions
excerpt: Unifying sizes, shapes, positions, and colors helps consistency, but depending on composition, optical illusions can cause unintended appearance. Know common illusion patterns and adjust visually when needed.

title: Support Spatial Memory
excerpt: Let users place objects anywhere on a 2D surface and remember them spatially. Save positions and restore them on next launch. Don't change them arbitrarily for system convenience.

title: Prospective Memory
excerpt: Let users leave cues for their future self. Allow bookmarking or flagging content, keeping windows open, using virtual sticky notes or markers, and saving drafts so they can return later.

title: Touch Targets >= 7mm
excerpt: On touchscreens, make buttons and controls at least 7-10 mm square so they are easy to press. Since fingers occlude targets, add spacing to prevent mis-taps.

title: Direct Manipulation Gestures
excerpt: Make gesture responses follow input directly, with the target element tracking the gesture. Gestures that simply trigger commands via predetermined symbolic motions are hard to learn because the mapping is arbitrary.

title: Drill-Down: Top to Bottom
excerpt: When splitting the screen into panes for hierarchical navigation, show the content of the item selected above below, and the content of the item selected on the left to the right. For RTL languages, reverse left and right.

title: Left Back, Right Forward
excerpt: If screen transitions are represented along a horizontal axis, map left to back (past) and right to forward (future). For RTL languages, reverse left and right relationships.

title: Mobile: Hierarchical Over Comprehensive
excerpt: Desktop apps benefit from showing a comprehensive overview, but on mobile it's better to limit information shown at once and present it hierarchically.

title: Keep Simple Things Simple
excerpt: As products mature and add features, common simple functions can get buried among advanced ones. Don't let tasks that were easy in a simple product require complex operations in a mature one.

title: Don't Overuse Color or Type
excerpt: Colors and typefaces can emphasize elements and indicate groups, but using too many makes screens messy; use them sparingly.

title: Lay Out Neatly
excerpt: Lay out screen elements neatly along a grid. Use repetition and consistency in spacing and alignment. This creates visual stability and logically conveys structure.

title: Don't Rely on Customization
excerpt: Relying on customization to handle slightly different needs per user increases complexity and can reduce learnability and maintainability. Decide on the best UI spec first, and offer customization cautiously and minimally.

title: Make It the User's Tool
excerpt: Build the system as something that belongs to users, not providers. It should not be a tool to impose provider demands, but a tool that amplifies users' actions. Think of it not as something that makes users do things, but something users use to do things.

title: Let Users Work Their Way
excerpt: Prefer modeless tools over procedures that must be memorized. Inventing better ways to use a tool is a source of creativity; aim for designs that foster mutual evolution between people and tools.

title: Help Users Learn
excerpt: If users have domain experience, they should be able to use the system on their own. Don't write usage instructions into the interface; make the interface self-explanatory so how to use it is obvious.

title: Don't Lock the UI
excerpt: In a GUI, work proceeds by repeating: 1. user action -> 2. processing -> 3. result display. UI locking is when processing takes so long that results don't appear and the UI stops accepting the next action. If the UI is locked for more than a few seconds, users lose the feeling that they freely control the application.

title: Don't Bring Games Into It
excerpt: Users want to achieve goals, not play a game (unless it is a game app). Don't include game-like elements in interfaces: randomness, surprise, gambling, obscurity, speed demands, dexterity demands, intuition demands, and so on.

title: Move as Users Intend
excerpt: Interfaces should respond to user input, but to make users feel in control, don't reflect raw input-device values directly; include appropriate slack and correction.

title: Increase Hot Spots
excerpt: Make the tappable or clickable area for buttons larger than the visible rectangle. This balances visual design with ease of pressing. But don't separate the visible element from the hotspot.

title: Support Screen Readers
excerpt: For use with screen readers and voice browsers, provide alternative text for non-text information such as images. Follow standard platform specifications to improve accessibility.

title: Support Text Enlargement
excerpt: Support larger text sizes via platform or browser text enlargement features. Implement text rendering according to standard specifications to improve accessibility.

title: Don't Rely on Color
excerpt: Don't make the interface depend on color. Ensure information is conveyed without color using contrast, borders and underlines, mapping by shape or position, and textual annotations. Verify by viewing the interface in grayscale.

title: Let Users Work at Their Pace
excerpt: Don't impose time limits on actions. Don't change operation validity based on timing. Don't require fast reflexes. Users want control, not challenge (except games).

title: Create the User Illusion
excerpt: Through capacity and speed, computers can hide internal mechanisms and present objects within a virtual world so users can focus. Provide illusions such as infinitely nestable folders or instantly delivered email.

title: Design Proposes New Meaning
excerpt: Many innovative designs draw on external cues like understanding user needs and researching behavior, but their essence appears as proposals of meaning born from designers' internal reflection. Design doesn't only solve problems; it leads to new ways of seeing things.

title: Positive Impact
excerpt: Tool design is not merely for short-term goal achievement. It serves humanity by being tolerant of human shortcomings and enhancing human strengths, enriching life. We inherit the culture accumulated within design.
